Third layer.gif) ::: ::: {.callout title="Reading list"} - Ch64 Fibularis longus, brevis, tertius muscle @donnellyTravellSimonsSimons2019 - Neuman @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 - MMT @weinstockNeuroKineticTherapyInnovative2010 ::: ::: {#tbl-oian .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Fibularis longus Proximal lateral surface of Fibula Medial cuneiform
Base of 1st MT		 Superficial Fibular n.
L5 - S1		 TCJ: PF
STJ: Eversion
Arch: Transverse arch support
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} Proximal lateral surface of the fibiula @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Insertion {#insertion} - Medial cuneiform @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Base of 1st MT @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Innervation {#innervation} [Superficial Fibular N.]({{< var ref-superficial-fibular-nerve.path >}}) ([L5]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l5 >}}), [S1]({{< var ref-nerve-root.s1 >}})) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Action {#action} - **TCJ**: Plantarflexion @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - **STJ**: Eversion @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - **Transverse arch**: Support @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 The fibularis longus also plays a role in calcaneal frontal plane stabilization. Although it does not *insert* on the calcaneus, the fibularis longus tendon "hooks" onto the calcaneus allowing it to exert a force upon the calcaneus @jonesProjectFoundations2025. The fibularis longus tendon can control and prevent excessive calcaneal valgus/abduction @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Tendon "The tendon of the fibularis (peroneus) longus runs superficially behind the lateral malleolus. Resisted pronation and plantar flexion of the foot make the tendon more prominent" @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020
